speaker: Alice
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil.

speaker: Alice
text: Could you lend me some dosh, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Sure. How much do you need?

speaker: Alice
text: A couple of smackers.

speaker: Neil
text: You're sounding strange today, Alice.

speaker: SlangDoshsmacker
text: Yes, I know, Neil. Slang – or informal language used by a particular group – is the subject of today's show, and I was just demonstrating a couple of slang words that mean 'money'. Dosh is a general term for money and a smacker is a British pound or US dollar.

speaker: Cockney Rhyming Slang
text: OK, so Cockney Rhyming Slang is a type of slang. It's a coded language invented in the 19th Century by Cockneys so they could speak in front of the police without being understood. And still on the subject of money, I have a question for you, Alice.

speaker: Alice
text: OK.

speaker: Neil
text: What's Cockney Rhyming Slang for 'money'? Is it…

speaker: Neil
text: a) bread?

speaker: Neil
text: b) honey?

speaker: Neil
text: Or c) dough?

speaker: Alice
text: I think it's a) bread. I bet you didn't know, Neil, that I'm a Cockney.

speaker: Neil
text: I don't Adam and Eve it, Alice! That's a pork pie!

speaker: Alice
text: 'Adam and Eve' means 'believe' and 'pork pie' means… 'lie'! Actually, you're right. I'm not a Cockney.

speaker: Neil
text: To be considered a Cockney, you need to be born within hearing distance of the bells of St Mary-le-Bow church in what is now the City of London.

speaker: colloquial
text: Indeed. Now, slang, as we've said, is colloquial – or informal – language. And it's characteristic of specific social groups. We usually use it in informal conversation rather than in writing or more formal situations, like a job interview.

speaker: Neil
text: We change the way we speak so that what we say is appropriate for a particular situation. So you surprised me, earlier, Alice, by talking about 'dosh' and 'smackers' because it didn't seem appropriate for presenting the show.

speaker: frowned upon
text: Slang use is often frowned upon – or disapproved of. Let's listen to Jonathan Green, a lexicographer of slang, talking about who uses slang and how this has changed. Here he is on the Radio 4 programme Word of Mouth.

speaker: Jonathan Green, lexicographer of slang
text: Slang does have a bad reputation and I would say this comes from its earliest collection, which was of criminal slang in the 1500s in the 16th century, and it was associated with bad people, and inevitably that has lingered. But now in the last 40 or 50 years it's changed. The definitions tend to stress 'different' and 'jocular', 'funny', 'humorous', 'inventive', that kind of thing.

speaker: lingered
text: So we have records of 16th Century slang in collections – or dictionaries. Words used by criminals as a code so they could talk without being understood. And this bad reputation has lingered – or been slow to disappear.

speaker: booze
text: But for the last 50 years we've been using slang to be funny and creative as well as to show belonging to a particular group. And apparently we're very creative when talking about drinking and being drunk. The slang word booze – meaning 'alcohol' – comes from the 13th Century Dutch word, 'būsen'.

speaker: Neil
text: And there are hundreds of slang expressions to talk about drink and being drunk: 'on the sauce', 'in your cups', 'half cut', 'hammered', 'squiffy', 'tipsy', 'wasted', 'legless', and many many more that are far too rude to mention in this programme.

speaker: Alice
text: Yes. So, while these terms might not be strictly acceptable – or appropriate in formal contexts they aren't offensive, they are often amusing and help people bond in social groups.

speaker: swearprofanity
text: By contrast, swear words or profanity – means 'rude language that offends or upsets people'. And I'm not going to give any examples because that would be inappropriate and impolite, Alice.

speaker: Alice
text: OK, let's listen now to Jonathan Green and presenter Michael Rosen talking about jargon – another type of in-group language.

speaker: Jonathan Green, lexicographer of slang, and Michael Rosen, Presenter, Word of Mouth, Radio 4
text: JG: Jargon is what I would call is small 'o' occupational, small 'p' professional. It's closed off environments. You get legal jargon, you get naval jargon, I've been reading Patrick O'Brien recently and that's awash with futtock plates and fiddying the decks.

speaker: Jonathan Green, lexicographer of slang, and Michael Rosen, Presenter, Word of Mouth, Radio 4
text: MR: This is radio 4 Jonathan, be careful!

speaker: Neil
text: Jonathan Green in another segment of the BBC Radio 4 programme Word of Mouth. So he says jargon is occupational and professional, meaning people speak it at work, for example, lawyers and sailors. A futtock plate is, I believe, an iron plate attached to the top of a ship's mast. But I don't know much about this subject.

speaker: jargonoutsiders
text: That's the idea, though – jargon is the technical language belonging to a specific group. And to outsiders this jargon is often hard to understand.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes and here in the studio I can use all the radio jargon that I like. Look at my faders here, Alice. Going down and up and up and I'm just testing our levels…

speaker: Alice
text: Come on, live the fader alone. It controls the level of sound on a studio deck. Now it's time for the answer to today's quiz question, Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: I asked you: What's Cockney Rhyming Slang for money? Is it… a) bread, b) honey or c) dough?

speaker: Alice
text: And I said a) bread.

speaker: Neil
text: And you were right, Alice! Cockney Rhyming Slang uses just the first word of a phrase that rhymes with a word we're trying to disguise. So 'money' becomes 'bread and honey' but we just say 'bread'.
